newsitem.title: ECUADOR: Ecuador's Congress fires deputies for corruption.
newsitem.headline: Ecuador's Congress fires deputies for corruption.

text.p: Ecuador's Congress fired four deputies on Thursday as part of the caretaker government's anti-corruption campaign, legislators said.
In an extended session that ended early on Thursday, 63 of 77 deputies voted to oust the four, with the other 14 abstaining from the vote.

Leonidas Plaza and Humberto Delgado, both independents; Homero Lopez of the Roldosista Party and Patricio Almeida of the Radical Alfarista Front were ousted for violating an article of the Constitution prohibiting deputies from managing public funds.

"I protest this because everybody that should have been present was not. All the same, I will give myself up to the authorities and I will not flee the country," Plaza said after surrendering to police shortly after the session ended.
The whereabouts of the other three were unknown, although media reports on Wednesday said Lopez headed to Colombia.

The move was the second time Ecuador's Congress had ousted parliamentarians. Two weeks ago, Congress fired 13 deputies accused of mismanagement of budget funds -- the first time in Ecuador's history the legislature had taken such a step.
After the impeachment of President Abdala Bucaram in February, the 13 deputies involved said the funds were put aside to be spent on projects in their respective provinces.
Caretaker President Fabian Alarcon must call elections in May 1998.
